history.content:
Yes there is far more to EE than just circuits!

There are many EE's who never deal with circuits (I want to say there are more Electrical engineers that don't deal with circuits than do, though I have no numbers).   For instance the fields of signal processing, system design, control, etc.  The HKN course guide (https://hkn.eecs.berkeley.edu/courseguides) gives a good overview of the many branches in EE.  Historically, the reason these other fields were placed under "EE" was that these techniques were invented to solve the Telegrapher & other circuit equations (done by Oliver Heaviside, an electrical engineer who among other things condensed Maxwell's 20 equation down to the 4 we know of today and invented the techniques for solving differential equations, known today as Laplace's transforms), though these same techniques are now applied to many disciplines.

=======

Not all of EE is circuits. There are different subjects within EE like controls, signals & systems, etc that don't rely as heavily on circuits. You can take upper div EE courses like 126 (probability) or 127 (optimization) that won't deal with circuits at all. Something that helped me understand circuits, at least for test-taking, was to divorce it completely from the real world - instead understand circuits as diagrams equipped with certain rules for manipulating them. Then your job becomes much simpler, just 'shut up and calculate'.

=======

For EE 16B, you can refer to the course website to see for yourself what's covered.

From my experience, I'm in Spring 2018 EE 16B right now. The material up to midterm 1 deals a lot with circuits. Then after midterm 1, we start to generalize the circuit to different systems (pendulums, balancing a standing robot, making a toy car go straight, etc.), so you won't deal with circuits "directly," but the mathematical methods that you use to solve circuits earlier will definite stick around a lot (mostly linear algebra and differential equations). In addition, we've also started learning more theoretical (or mathematics) material such as the SVD and PCA.

I'm also in EE 127, which does not deal with circuits at all. The material is rather mathematics heavy, and has a lot of applications in machine learning.

Yes there is far more to EE than just circuits!

There are many EE's who never deal with circuits (I want to say there are more Electrical engineers that don't deal with circuits than do, though I have no numbers).   For instance the fields of signal processing, system design, control, etc.  The HKN course guide (https://hkn.eecs.berkeley.edu/courseguides) gives a good overview of the many branches in EE.  Historically, the reason these other fields were placed under "EE" was that these techniques were invented to solve the Telegrapher & other circuit equations (done by Oliver Heaviside, an electrical engineer who among other things condensed Maxwell's 20 equation down to the 4 we know of today and invented the techniques for solving differential equations, known today as Laplace's transforms), though these same techniques are now applied to many disciplines.

*MOST* of EE has nothing to do with circuits.  We have many brilliant faculty on the EE side of the 

department who probably hate circuits more than you do.

Most of the courses that we offer have nothing to do with circuits:

robotics 106AB

optics, photonics, fields and waves: 117, 118

systems, control, random processes, communication, DSP, 120, 121, 122, 123, 125, 126, 127, 128

semiconductor physics & processing, photovoltaics, power systems 130, 134, 137AB (a little bit of circuits here, but surprisingly little), 143

modeling and optimization 144

MEMS 147

embedded systems 149

mechatronics 192  (again, a very little bit of circuits in these last three, but you can do great with basically zero understanding of circuits)

and then there are a few circuits courses: 105, 140, 142, 151.  They are awesome if you like circuits.

department who probably hate circuits more than you do.

Most of the courses that we offer have nothing to do with circuits:

robotics 106AB

optics, photonics, fields and waves: 117, 118

systems, control, communication, DSP, 120, 123, 125, 128

semiconductor physics & processing, photovoltaics, power systems 130, 134, 137AB (a little bit of circuits here, but surprisingly little), 143

modeling and optimization 144

MEMS 147

embedded systems 149

mechatronics 192  (again, a very little bit of circuits in these last three, but you can do great with basically zero understanding of circuits)

and then there are a few circuits courses: 105, 140, 142, 151.  They are awesome if you like circuits.

If I am currently being smacked in the face in the circuits module of EE16A in terms circuit intuition and understanding how different types of op amps, etc work, how much of 16B and upperdiv EE courses build upon these fundamental circuit concepts? Are there EE upperdivs that depend less on circuits and more on other topics in EE, and if so, what interesting topics do they branch into?
history.subject: How Much Of EE is Circuits?
